bioghist.p: George Lippard (1822-1854) was a 19th century American novelist, journalist, playwright, social activist, and labor organizer. In 1850 Lippard founded the Brotherhood of the Union, a secret benevolent society with rituals and symbols drawn from the Masons and Odd-Fellows. The organization was later renamed the Brotherhood of America; it dissolved in 1995.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of writings, correspondence, and printed materials related to the Brotherhood of the Union. Materials include: an 1850 Charter of Circle 142 of the Brotherhood of the Union; printed circulars and broadsides; manuscript letters from Lippard to William Macfarlane and James Stevens; and two volumes: Lippard's Diary (1852-1869), which contains Lippard's notes about the Brotherhood from 1852 to 1854, and which was continued by Lippard's successors as a record-book of the Supreme Washington; and a record book (1859-1879), which includes minutes, resolutions, by-laws, and financial records. The collection also includes photographs of Lippard's residence taken in the 1930s, of his gravestone taken in 1980, and of G.J. Ehmann conferring the G.E.W. Degee in 1973.
